subject: Re: [junit] Re: HOW TO ASK QUESTIONS ON THIS GROUP - also ...
msgSnippet: ... A FAQ, though, may have provided a short answer to this question - and perhaps that would be sufficient for the poster. (And if not, he could always ask a
messageBody:
At 09:54 AM 16/10/01, you wrote:
>--- In junit@y..., Eric Vought <evought@q...> wrote:
>and
>--- In junit@y..., "J. B. Rainsberger" <jbrains762@h...> wrote:
>.....
> >Ladies and Gentlemen:
> >
> >I am frankly quite concerned with the quality of the exchanges
> >going on here in the last several weeks. It appears that many
> >people think there are "magic formulas" for working with JUnit.
> >As a result, they ask silly questions like, "How do I test an
> >EJB with JUnit????" The people who know the answer get so
> >tired of writing, "Search this list. Try it. What are you
> >having trouble testing?" that they simply stop responding.
> >As a result, questions are not being answered.
>................
>
>I don't agree with these opinions. I think there has been
>very good questions and answers (discussions) here. Of course
>it is good if the answers can already be found in a FAQ
>but remember that the FAQ is something that is maintained
>usually by one person as on a list like this you can have several
>views. Take as an example the answers yesterday of why you should use
>JUnit. I am sure you can find data on this already somewhere else.


A FAQ, though, may have provided a short answer to this question - and
perhaps that would be sufficient for the poster. (And if not, he could
always ask a question ;)

I'm fully in favour of anything that cuts down on list volume - if this
were the only list to which I'm subscribed, it wouldn't matter... but what
with this one, ant-users, tomcat-users, ...




>JUnit is a new thing for many people and this list must also be
>available to new users and not only to those who have already
>got an answer to all questions.


You're 100% right - but so many of the questions here are so basic that
they show that the person has done *no* research whatsoever - kind of like
the questions you get on usenet that are so obviously the questioner's
homework. New users' questions are of course welcome - but as has been
pointed out, it's only polite to try and find the answer first.



Jim








--

* Jim Cheesman *
Trabajo:
jchees@... - (34)(91) 724 9200 x 2360
Cooperation can only be
reached if we work together.
